required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Antioxidant Vitamins on Coagulopathy and Nosocomial Pneumonia After Severe Trauma
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Antioxidant Vitamins on Coagulopathy and Nosocomial Pneumonia After Severe Trauma

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine the effect of antioxidant vitamins (vitamins C and E) on the development of coagulation derangements and nosocomial pneumonia after severe trauma in patients.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Inability to recruit patients that meet inclusion criteria.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Coagulation Abnormalities
primary_outcome.description: Coagulation parameters are evaluated using standard functional tests (prothrombin time (PT), partial thromboplastin time (PTT), fibrinogen and platelet count)and point of care functional analysis using thromboelastogram (TEG-ROTEM). A blood sample is collected upon arrival in the emergency department at 0 hours only and analyzed for markers of activation of coagulation, inflammation, and levels of vitamin C/E.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects With Ventilator-associated Pneumonia.
primary_outcome.description: Number of subjects diagnosed with pneumonia and requiring ventilator support.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects With Organ Injury
primary_outcome.description: Any injury to internal organs (thoracic, abdominal or cranial cavity)

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Total Blood Product Transfusions
primary_outcome.description: the number of blood product transfusions for all subjects in each group over the course of 3 days.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Protocol Violations Per Arm.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 60 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: The number of times that there was a deviation or violation from how the protocol was to be implemented.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects Surviving to Day 28
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 28 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects that survived to day 28 after enrollment

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 60 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects in each arm that survived to day 60

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Ventilator-free Days for Subjects
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 60 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: The mean number of ventilator free days (not on ventilator) for subjects in each arm

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Days in ICU.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 60 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: the mean number of days each subject was in the ICU in each arm

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Hospital Stay Days.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from enrollment up to 60 days post enrollment
secondary_outcome.description: The mean number of days subjects were in the hospital in each arm of the study

arm_group.description: Vitamin C (1,000 mg i.v.) and Vitamin E (1,000 IU p.o. via the naso-gastric tube) administered every 8 hours starting within one hour after admission to the Emergency department for up to 5 days or until discharge from the ICU, whichever comes first.

100 ml of 0.9% saline (for i.v. Vitamin C) and a p.o. placebo (sugar pill for the p.o. Vitamin E) administered every 8 hours starting within one hour after admission to the Emergency department for up to 5 days or until discharge from the ICU, whichever comes first.

intervention.description: 0.9% saline administered to mimic Vitamin C
Sugar pill administered to mimic Vitamin E

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult trauma patients admitted to the emergency department at the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) Hospital
- Blunt or penetrating injury
- UAB highest trauma activation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age < 19 years of age
- Patients with known bleeding diathesis or who are concurrently taking anticoagulant medication
- Patients with known liver disease
- Minor patients
- Pregnant patients (known or suspected pregnancy)
- Patients who are incarcerated
- Patients who lack a surrogate

overall_official.affiliation: The University of Alabama at Birmingham
The University of Alabama at Birmingham

facility.name: The University of Alabama at Birmingham Hospital

reference.citation: Brohi K, Cohen MJ, Ganter MT, Matthay MA, Mackersie RC, Pittet JF. Acute traumatic coagulopathy: initiated by hypoperfusion: modulated through the protein C pathway? Ann Surg. 2007 May;245(5):812-8.

Brohi K, Cohen MJ, Ganter MT, Schultz MJ, Levi M, Mackersie RC, Pittet JF. Acute coagulopathy of trauma: hypoperfusion induces systemic anticoagulation and hyperfibrinolysis. J Trauma. 2008 May;64(5):1211-7; discussion 1217. doi: 10.1097/TA.0b013e318169cd3c.

Chesebro BB, Rahn P, Carles M, Esmon CT, Xu J, Brohi K, Frith D, Pittet JF, Cohen MJ. Increase in activated protein C mediates acute traumatic coagulopathy in mice. Shock. 2009 Dec;32(6):659-65. doi: 10.1097/SHK.0b013e3181a5a632.

Cohen MJ, Bir N, Rahn P, Dotson R, Brohi K, Chesebro BB, Mackersie R, Carles M, Wiener-Kronish J, Pittet JF. Protein C depletion early after trauma increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia. J Trauma. 2009 Dec;67(6):1176-81. doi: 10.1097/TA.0b013e3181c1c1bc.

Nathens AB, Neff MJ, Jurkovich GJ, Klotz P, Farver K, Ruzinski JT, Radella F, Garcia I, Maier RV. Randomized, prospective trial of antioxidant supplementation in critically ill surgical patients. Ann Surg. 2002 Dec;236(6):814-22.

Collier BR, Giladi A, Dossett LA, Dyer L, Fleming SB, Cotton BA. Impact of high-dose antioxidants on outcomes in acutely injured patients. JPEN J Parenter Enteral Nutr. 2008 Jul-Aug;32(4):384-8. doi: 10.1177/0148607108319808.

Secor D, Li F, Ellis CG, Sharpe MD, Gross PL, Wilson JX, Tyml K. Impaired microvascular perfusion in sepsis requires activated coagulation and P-selectin-mediated platelet adhesion in capillaries. Intensive Care Med. 2010 Nov;36(11):1928-34. doi: 10.1007/s00134-010-1969-3. Epub 2010 Aug 6.
Brohi K, Singh J, Heron M, Coats T. Acute traumatic coagulopathy. J Trauma. 2003 Jun;54(6):1127-30.
MacLeod JB, Lynn M, McKenney MG, Cohn SM, Murtha M. Early coagulopathy predicts mortality in trauma. J Trauma. 2003 Jul;55(1):39-44.
Esmon CT. The protein C pathway. Chest. 2003 Sep;124(3 Suppl):26S-32S. Review.

Giladi AM, Dossett LA, Fleming SB, Abumrad NN, Cotton BA. High-dose antioxidant administration is associated with a reduction in post-injury complications in critically ill trauma patients. Injury. 2011 Jan;42(1):78-82. doi: 10.1016/j.injury.2010.01.104. Epub 2010 Feb 10.

group.title: Vitamins C and E
group.description: Vitamin C (1,000 mg i.v.) and Vitamin E (1,000 IU p.o. via the naso-gastric tube) administered every 8 hours starting within one hour after admission to the Emergency department for up to 5 days or until discharge from the ICU, whichever comes first. Vitamin C Vitamin E

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Study terminated--inability to recruit patient that met inclusion criteria.
